org.md2k.demoapp

Class MainActivity

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.content.Context
      • android.content.ContextWrapper
        • android.view.ContextThemeWrapper
          • android.app.Activity

  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.content.ComponentCallbacks, android.content.ComponentCallbacks2, android.hardware.SensorEventListener, android.support.v4.app.ActivityCompat.OnRequestPermissionsResultCallback, android.support.v4.app.ActivityCompatApi23.RequestPermissionsRequestCodeValidator, android.support.v4.app.TaskStackBuilder.SupportParentable, android.support.v7.app.ActionBarDrawerToggle.DelegateProvider, android.support.v7.app.AppCompatCallback, android.view.KeyEvent.Callback, android.view.LayoutInflater.Factory, android.view.LayoutInflater.Factory2, android.view.View.OnCreateContextMenuListener, android.view.Window.Callback

    public class MainActivity
extends android.support.v7.app.AppCompatActivity
implements android.hardware.SensorEventListener
    This application demonstrates how to connect to and make API calls against DataKit via DataKitAPI.

        Constant Field Values

      • subscribeListener

        public OnReceiveListener subscribeListener
        OnReceiveListener used for subscription. This demo application simply displays the data to an output text view.

    • Method Detail

      • onCreate

        protected void onCreate(android.os.Bundle savedInstanceState)
        Upon creation, the buttons, SensorManager, Sensor, and current datetime are initialized. An instance of DataKit is also retrieved/created.
        Overrides:
        onCreate in class android.support.v7.app.AppCompatActivity
        Parameters:
        savedInstanceState - Previous state of the application if available.

      • buildApplication

        public Application buildApplication()
        Builds a new application object. This object represents this application and helps identify data within the database.
        Returns:
        Application datatype

      • buildDataSource

        public DataSourceBuilder buildDataSource(Application application)
        Builds a data source object representing the sensor and application creating the data source. This demo application only uses the accelerometer, but any available sensor, hardware or software based, can be used.
        Parameters:
        application - Application object representing this application.
        Returns:
        A data source builder

      • buildDataSource

        public DataSourceBuilder buildDataSource()
        Builds a data source object representing the sensor. In this application this is only used for registering the data source. It could be used to find all data sources of the set type independent from the application.
        Returns:
        A data source builder

      • setHFSwitch

        public void setHFSwitch(android.view.View view)
        Switch mechanism for switching between insertData() and insertHFData. This is not necessary in a typical application, but used to demonstrate the difference between these two data insert methods.
        Parameters:
        view - hfSwitch

      • connectButton

        public void connectButton(android.view.View view)
        Controls behavior of connecting and disconnecting from DataKit. DataKit must be connected before any other methods are called. Not doing so will result in DataKitExceptions which must be handled. DataKitAPI.connect(new OnConnectionListener() registers a callback interface so that this application and DataKit can communicate.
        Parameters:
        view - conButton

      • disconnectDataKit

        public void disconnectDataKit()
        Before DataKit is disconnected, all data sources must be unsubscribed and unregistered. Exception checking is not required when calling DataKitAPI.disconnect().

      • registerButton

        public void registerButton(android.view.View view)
        Registers the data source with DataKit. DataKit can not receive data from a data source until that data source is registered.
        Parameters:
        view - regButton

      • unregisterButton

        public void unregisterButton(boolean failed)
        Unregistering the sensor listener stops the data collection. Unsubscibing the data source removes any remaining callbacks. Then unregistering the data source from DataKit can be done. It is possible to unregister a subset of registered data sources, but DataKitAPI.unregister() only takes one DataSourceClient as a parameter so the method would need to be called individually for each data source.
        Parameters:
        failed - Whether this method was called because data source registration failed or not. Only used for error message handling.

      • unregisterListener

        public void unregisterListener()
        Unregisters the sensor listener. To pass this as the sensor listener, the class must implement SensorEventListener.

      • subscribeButton

        public void subscribeButton(android.view.View view)
        Subscribing a data source registers a callback interface that returns the data received by the database. In this implementation dataSourceClients only has one node because the only sensor that is registered is the accelerometer. In production the resulting arraylist is likely to have many more nodes.
        Parameters:
        view - subButton

      • unsubscribeDataSource

        public void unsubscribeDataSource()
        Unsubscribing a data source only unregisters the callback interface. Data is still collected and inserted. Nullifying the associated DataSourceClient variable prevents conflicts if the data source is subscribed again.

      • insertButton

        public void insertButton(android.view.View view)
        In this implementation, pressing the insert button only registers the sensor listener. All data collection occurs in the overridden onSensorChanged() method.
        Parameters:
        view - insButton

      • onSensorChanged

        public void onSensorChanged(android.hardware.SensorEvent event)
        To limit the frequency of samples a minimum sample time of 100 milliseconds. The accelerometer is sampled at 10 hertz and is adjusted for gravity before being passed into a new DataTypeDoubleArray. An appropriate DataType for the sensor should be used. For example, motion sensors should use DataTypeDoubleArray because they return an array of double values. The proximity sensor and other environmental sensors should use DataTypeDouble, as they return an array with only one value.
        Specified by:
        onSensorChanged in interface android.hardware.SensorEventListener
        Parameters:
        event - Value of the new accelerometer data.

      • insertData

        public void insertData(DataTypeDoubleArray data)
        Data is inserted into the database using the associated DataSourceClient, which provides relevant metadata, and the data sample itself. This demo also displays the data that is inserted, but that is not necessary. The standard insertion method adds rows to a database that is stored in Android/Data/org.md2k.datakit/files/database.db by default. Using insertHighFrequency() is recommended for sensors that produce a lot of data, such as the accelerometer, to help manage the size of the database.
        Parameters:
        data - Data to insert into the database

      • insertHFData

        public void insertHFData(DataTypeDoubleArray data)
        Data is passed to insertHighFrequency() similarly to insert(). The difference is that the high frequency data is stored in a gzipped csv file that is stored in Android/Data/org.md2k.datakit/files/raw/ by default. Recording the data in this way helps reduce the amount of resources DataKit requires.
        Parameters:
        data - Data to record.

      • onAccuracyChanged

        public void onAccuracyChanged(android.hardware.Sensor sensor,
                              int x)
        Specified by:
        onAccuracyChanged in interface android.hardware.SensorEventListener

      • queryButton

        public void queryButton(android.view.View view)
        Queries the database for data matching the given data source and parameters. This demo application only shows one query method. In this example, an arraylist of DataSourceClients matching the desired data source is produced using the DataKitAPI.find() method. DataKitAPI.find() takes a DataSourceBuilder object as a parameter. This DataSourceBuilder can be configured for a particular data source or application. The query call is performed by passing a DataSourceClient and an integer representing the "last n samples" that were collected. Using this query method returns the last n rows matching the given data source in the database, where n is the number of samples to return.

        Other query methods allow queries for a given time window:

        DataKitAPI.query(DataSourceClient dataSourceClient, long starttimestamp, long endtimestamp)

        Or querying via primary key, where lastSyncedKey is the primary key and limit is the number of rows to return:

        queryFromPrimaryKey(DataSourceClient dataSourceClient, long lastSyncedKey, int limit)

        All DataKitAPI.query() methods return an arraylist of DataType objects. DataKitAPI.queryFromPrimaryKey returns an arraylist of RowObjects.

        Another useful method demonstrated here is DataKitAPI.querySize() which returns the number of rows in the database as a DataTypeLong object.

        Parameters:
        view - queButton

      • printQuery

        public void printQuery(java.util.ArrayList<DataType> query)
        This is an example of how a query result might be printed.
        Parameters:
        query - Query result

      • printSample

        public void printSample(DataTypeDoubleArray data,
                        android.widget.TextView output)
        Prints a data sample. Used for displaying inserted data and data received when a data source is subscribed.
        Parameters:
        data - Data sample to print.
        output - TextView to print to.
